body.p: Julie A. Carlson is Professor of English and Associate Dean/Faculty Equity Advisor in the Division of Humanities and Fine Arts at UC Santa Barbara. She is author of In the Theatre of Romanticism: Coleridge, Nationalism, Women (Cambridge UP, 1994), England's First Family of Writers: Mary Wollstonecraft, William Godwin, Mary Shelley (Johns Hopkins UP, 2007), and coeditor with Elisabeth Weber of Speaking About Torture (Fordham UP, 2012). Her current work is on the interconnection between friendship and creativity as the radical legacy of white Romantic-era writing.

Elizabeth A. Fay is Professor of English at the University of Massachusetts Boston. She specializes in British Romantic literature. Her most recent monograph is Romantic Egypt: Abyssal Ground of British Romanticism (Lexington Books, 2021). She has also published five previous monographs, including Fashioning Faces: The Portraitive Mode in British Romanticism (UPNE, 2010) and Romantic Medievalism: History and the Romantic Literary Ideal (Palgrave, 2002). Her current project is Romantic Immanence, forthcoming from SUNY Press.

David Sigler is Associate Professor of English at the University of Calgary, specializing in British Romanticism and literary theory. He is the author of Sexual Enjoyment in British Romanticism: Gender and Psychoanalysis 1753–1835 (McGill-Queenʼs UP, 2015) and of Fracture Feminism: The Politics of Impossible Time in British Romanticism (SUNY Press, 2021). He is coeditor, with Daniela Garofalo, of Lacan and Romanticism (SUNY Press, 2019) and editor of Women and War, vol 2: British Women and War 1660–1835 (Routledge History of Feminism Series, 2020).

Kate Singer is Associate Professor of English at Mount Holyoke College and a member of the Critical Social Thought program. She has published Romantic Vacancy: The Poetics of Gender, Affect, and Radical Speculation (SUNY Press, 2019) and has coedited, with Ashley J. Cross and Suzanne L. Barnett, Material Transgressions: Beyond Romantic Bodies, Genders, Things (Liverpool UP, 2020). She coedits the Pedagogies section of Romantic Circles and is currently at work on a book about Romantic shapeshifting and ontologies of change.
